text: love this advice above and agree, it's all about transparency. "100% open rate" on an email 1 person got is misleading unless you tell me the sample size. Highlight statistics that tell the most accurate and useful story to your reader!

text:
The short answer: YouTube is a different game. CTR + watch time are the key metrics.

As a baseline: You need 75% of the people who see your video to click it.

Then 75% of those people to watch 75% of the video.

elements.text:

text: Welp, it happened, so maybe you can give an exclusive tone to the copy. Say things like "a select group of xyz" instead of "a limited number of respondents". Also, things like "an exclusive sample of 10 xyz indicated that...". I think the best way to go is to spin it as hyper personalization toward your sample, as long as it's true. For example,  as a social media marketer, maybe i'd rather hear from 10 SMM than 100 generalists.

For example,  as a social media marketer, maybe i'd rather hear from 10 SMM than 100 generalists.

Hey Vanessa! You should check out this interview of Sam Oh (Head of Video at Ahrefs) by Kevin Indig.

That’s how Ahrefs started with their YouTube channel. Turning their best performing pieces, turning it into video, and embedding it back to the article

I’m in the same process of doing the same thing at Appcues

<https://www.kevin-indig.com/the-art-of-video-storytelling-w-sam-oh/>

text:
Oh my gosh, I'm late to the party on this thread, but this is literally all I do all day long at <http://useprocket.com|useprocket.com>. I've set up a really systematized process that I now train our writers on. Here is the process in a nutshell and I am more than happy to chat via DM:
1. Transcribe the podcast/webinar (we use Descript)
2. Identify the top 10 key takeaways (paragraphs). This forces you to identify the heart of the convo
3. Give each of those takeaways a title + use them to inspire a blog outline, then flesh out using a mixture of quotes and synthesis
4. Use sections of the blog to inspire LinkedIn posts
5. Whittle down your LinkedIn posts to Tweets

elements.text: Oh my gosh, I'm late to the party on this thread, but this is literally all I do all day long at
useprocket.com
. I've set up a really systematized process that I now train our writers on. Here is the process in a nutshell and I am more than happy to chat via DM:
Transcribe the podcast/webinar (we use Descript)
Identify the top 10 key takeaways (paragraphs). This forces you to identify the heart of the convo
Give each of those takeaways a title + use them to inspire a blog outline, then flesh out using a mixture of quotes and synthesis
Use sections of the blog to inspire LinkedIn posts
Whittle down your LinkedIn posts to Tweets

text: Hey everyone! What platform /CMS do you use to host your company/product blog? And why would you say it’s a good choice?

elements.text: Hey everyone! What platform /CMS do you use to host your company/product blog? And why would you say it’s a good choice?

text: We use Wordpress, it's pretty great, mostly because all our developers know how to use it and it's easy to learn and there are a ton of people with experience using it.

elements.text: We use Wordpress, it's pretty great, mostly because all our developers know how to use it and it's easy to learn and there are a ton of people with experience using it.

text: We are wordpress too, very easy to onboard folks because its so widely known/understood.

elements.text: We are wordpress too, very easy to onboard folks because its so widely known/understood.

text: We have been on Webflow for years but we are just outgrowing it. I'll say that it's very easy to create pages if you have a great design team experienced in using it, but it's a horrible CMS for content creators. Currently lots of limits on user roles, versioning, etc. We are going to give Webflow Enterprise a look but we will likely move to WPEngine (essentially WordPress). We are looking at other platforms like Contentful and Craft as well.

elements.text: We have been on Webflow for years but we are just outgrowing it. I'll say that it's very easy to create pages if you have a great design team experienced in using it, but it's a horrible CMS for content creators. Currently lots of limits on user roles, versioning, etc. We are going to give Webflow Enterprise a look but we will likely move to WPEngine (essentially WordPress). We are looking at other platforms like Contentful and Craft as well.

text: We have a great content operation for creating articles, reports, and ebooks, but don't have a ton of experience translating that content into infographics or interactive pieces. FYI - we don't have a full-time copywriter in-house at the moment, but have that hire on the roadmap soon! Would love to hear how your teams are managing producing these sorts of pieces. Are you using in-house copywriter + designer? Are you using agencies? Thanks!

text: <@U027V14CNHF> I will say there are trade offs to Webflow that may be worth it! Like the ability to build in iterate your website without developers. I remember a previous companies having to do a deploy every time I wanted to launch anything on the website that wasn’t just through wordpress. That’s not a problem with webflow. But you do give up functionally that’s helpful to the content team. Happy to report back when we decide

text: :slightly_smiling_face:

We also use Webflow at Appcues. We use it all for all of our content programs as well including ReallyGoodUX, Product-Led Growth Collective, and the Product Adoption Academy.

The great thing about it is how it gives you complete design freedom.

Webflow has a clean and good code quality, whereas WordPress code can become cluttered due to the extensive need for plugins.

elements.text:
We also use Webflow at Appcues. We use it all for all of our content programs as well including ReallyGoodUX, Product-Led Growth Collective, and the Product Adoption Academy.

The great thing about it is how it gives you complete design freedom.

Webflow has a clean and good code quality, whereas WordPress code can become cluttered due to the extensive need for plugins.

text: WordPress, no questions asked.

elements.text: WordPress, no questions asked.

text: We’ve had issues with limit in number of pages, SEO, and security compliance with Webflow. I think we could’ve lived with the other limitations with publishing at scale if it weren't for those major issues.

text: what issues with SEO <@U02UATYAC4X>?

elements.text: what issues with SEO

text: Anyone’s had experience with Ghost?

elements.text: Anyone’s had experience with Ghost?

text: This is v technical and in the weeds. Our SEO consultant pointed out "The way that Webflow complies CSS is not fully controlled by the user, this is likely not something that can be fixed unless Webflow decides to change their platform to better meat Google's standards for rendering." Also he pointed out that non-indexible URLs were appearing in the the Webflow auto-generated XML sitemaps. So we're having to do a custom XML sitemap.  Lastly - we can't install any kind of SEO-checking plugin like Yoast

elements.text: This is v technical and in the weeds. Our SEO consultant pointed out "The way that Webflow complies CSS is not fully controlled by the user, this is likely not something that can be fixed unless Webflow decides to change their platform to better meat Google's standards for rendering." Also he pointed out that non-indexible URLs were appearing in the the Webflow auto-generated XML sitemaps. So we're having to do a custom XML sitemap.  Lastly - we can't install any kind of SEO-checking plugin like Yoast
